feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued April 9 at 9:32AM EDT until April 9 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Pockets of shallow flooding less than one foot deep.
* WHERE...Eastern Essex MA, Suffolk MA, Eastern Norfolk MA, Eastern Plymouth MA and Barnstable MA Counties.
* WHEN...Until 2 PM EDT this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Shallow pockets of flooding less than one foot deep affects the most vulnerable coastal roads and lowest lying areas along the coast, such as Morrissey Boulevard in Boston. Roads remain passable.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...High astronomical tides may lead to rounds of very shallow flooding during some high tide cycles through Wednesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Essex; Suffolk; Eastern Norfolk; Eastern Plymouth; Barnstable

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD STATEMENT IN EFFECT UNTIL 2 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued April 9 at 8:31AM CDT until April 9 at 8:45AM CDT by NWS Lubbock TX
entry.summary:
At 830 AM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 6 miles northeast of Guthrie, moving northeast at 35 mph.
HAZARD...Ping pong ball size hail and 60 mph wind gusts.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect hail damage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles. Expect wind damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
This severe thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of south central King County.

cap:parameter.value: A SEVERE THUNDERSTORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 845 AM CDT FOR SOUTH CENTRAL KING COUNTY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 9 at 8:14AM CDT until April 9 at 12:15PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Urban area and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall overnight is ongoing.
* WHERE...Fannin county in North Texas.
* WHEN...Until 1215 PM CDT.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is ongoing from last night's heavy rain. Numerous roads remain closed due to flooding. Low-water crossings are inundated with water and may be impassable.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Emergency management reported ongoing flood impacts in the warned area due to thunderstorms overnight. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Bonham, Leonard, Honey Grove, Whitewright, Savoy, Ector, Trenton, Dodd City, Ravenna, Bonham State Park, Lake Bonham, Coffee Mill Lake, Randolph, Crockett Lake, Valley Lake, Boyd, Ladonia, Bailey, Pecan Gap and Windom.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 9 at 9:12AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Satilla River At Atkinson affecting Brantley County.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Wednesday morning at 915 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Satilla River at Atkinson.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Warners Landing, Louis Landing and secondary roads around KOA campgrounds begin to flood. At 14.0 feet, River Rock Road begins to experience flooding across the road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 13.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 13.1 feet Friday morning. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 9 at 9:04AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Columbia, Gilchrist and Suwannee Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Wednesday morning at 915 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:00 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 18.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 18.1 feet this afternoon. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Columbia, FL; Gilchrist, FL; Suwannee, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued April 9 at 7:57AM CDT until April 9 at 11:00AM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
FFWFWD
The National Weather Service in Fort Worth has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Anderson County in central Texas...
* Until 1100 AM CDT.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 9 at 8:41AM EDT until April 11 at 11:00AM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Indiana...
White River at Hazleton.
.Following one to four inches of rainfall over central and southern Indiana early last week...minor flooding continues on the lower White River at Petersburg and Hazleton. The crest on the White is near Petersburg.
Flooding on the White River is currently expected to come to an end over the next seven days, but rainfall over the next 10 days that has not yet been fully incorporated into the river forecasts has the potential to impact this expectation.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...White River at Hazleton.
* WHEN...Until late Thursday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 19.0 feet, Flood waters cover the Hazleton softball field. Pottsville Road is underwater and impassable.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - There is no current observed data. - Forecast...The river will rise to 18.6 feet this morning. It will then fall below flood stage late tomorrow evening to 15.2 feet early Thursday afternoon. It will rise to 15.4 feet Friday morning. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 16.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: High Wind Watch issued April 9 at 4:34AM AKDT until April 11 at 1:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...South winds 35 to 45 mph with gusts up to 60 mph possible.
* WHERE...The Central Brooks Range including the passes.
* WHEN...From Wednesday afternoon through Thursday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...High winds may move loose debris, damage property and cause power outages. Travel could be difficult especially for high profile vehicles.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...There will be snowfall on the southern slopes of the Brooks Range. With the strong southerly winds we could see blowing snow through the Brooks Range reducing visibilities below 1/2 miles at times.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Howard Pass and the Delong Mountains; Central Brooks Range

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 9 at 7:17AM CDT by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary: Areas of fog occasionally reducing visibility to around one- quarter mile have developed across portions of west-central and northwest Minnesota. Travelers should be prepared for rapidly deteriorating visibility, and to use extra caution at intersections, railroad crossings, and school bus stops. The fog is expected to improve by 10 AM.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 9 at 3:45AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary: As of 3 AM this morning, an area of heavy snow has developed over Anchor Point and Homer. This area of snow will persist from Clam Gulch along the Sterling Highway south to Homer over the next couple of hours before moving out over Cook Inlet around 7 AM. Snowfall rates of one to two inches per hour are possible, resulting 1 to 4 inches of snow accumulation, with the highest amounts across the Homer Bluffs and Diamond Ridge. Visibilities may be reduced to one quarter mile or less in heavy snow. Motorists are urged to slow down and use caution when driving through heavy snow.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 9 at 2:58AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Bands of moderate to heavy snow showers will move across Eastern Kenai Peninsula and Eastern Turnagain Arm through Tuesday evening. The first of these bands will move through the area early to mid Tuesday morning with the second late Tuesday morning through mid Tuesday afternoon. Snowfall rates may approach 1 to 2 inches per hour in heavier snow showers, reducing visibility to as low as one quarter mile at times. Motorists are urged to slow down and use caution when driving through heavy snow showers.
The highest snowfall accumulations are expected along Portage Glacier Road, where 5 to 10 inches of snow could fall. Elsewhere along the Seward Highway, 2 to 6 inches of snow, with locally higher amounts, are possible. Any snow accumulations on area roads this morning may turn slushy or wet by afternoon as temperatures warm into the mid 30s.
entry.cap:areaDesc: East Turnagain Arm; Western Prince William Sound

cap:parameter.value: BANDS OF MODERATE TO HEAVY SNOW SHOWERS ACROSS EASTERN KENAI PENINSULA AND EASTERN TURNAGAIN ARM THROUGH TUESDAY EVENING

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Hazardous crosswinds are expected across north to south oriented roads and highways including Interstate 25 and Tramway Boulevard in east Albuquerque. The strongest winds will be at locations across east central and southeast Albuquerque downwind of Tijeras Canyon and at Mesa De Sol south of the Albuquerque Sunport.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Middle Rio Grande Valley/Albuquerque Metro Area; South Central Highlands

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 8 at 10:06PM EDT until April 10 at 11:00PM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Indiana...
White River at Petersburg.
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Indiana... Illinois...
White River at Edwardsport and at Hazleton.
Wabash River at Lafayette down to Riverton.
.Following one to four inches of rainfall over central and southern Indiana early last week...minor flooding continues on the Wabash River from Lafayette down to Riverton...and on the lower White River from Edwardsport and all points downriver. The crest on the Wabash is now below Terre Haute...and on the White it is almost to Petersburg.
Flooding on the Wabash and White rivers is currently expected to come to an end over the next seven days, but rainfall over the next 10 days that has not yet been fully incorporated into the river forecasts has the potential to impact this expectation, particularly on the Wabash.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Wabash River at Clinton.
* WHEN...Until late Wednesday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, River road near Mecca and lowest areas of river park at Clinton begin to flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - There is no current observed data. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late Wednesday morning and continue falling and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 18.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 8 at 1:36PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong storm will be moving into the Western Interior Wednesday evening into Thursday. This storm could produce wind gusts up to 35 mph and heavy snow. 8 to 12 inches of snow possible, with the heaviest snowfall over the Nulato Hills and the south slopes of the Brooks Range. Strong winds and heavy snow can produce snow drifts.
Residents should stay tuned to the latest forecast updates at www.weather.gov/afg and be prepared for upcoming winter weather.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 8 at 3:55PM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
ESFTAE
.Antecedent Conditions... Over the last two to four weeks, rainfall has been much above normal in South Central Georgia and into portions of the Florida Big Bend. Further west into Southwest Georgia, Southeast Alabama and the Florida Panhandle rainfall has been below normal. Even with below normal rainfall in the western half of the region, streamflows and soil conditions are running at normal levels or even above normal levels for this time of year in the eastern half of the region. These conditions set the stage for the potential for both flash flooding and riverine flooding should heavy rainfall occur.
.Forecast and Outlook... A strong storm system will move into the region on Wednesday evening and exit the area by Thursday afternoon. Even though the system will move through the region fairly quickly, the potential exists for very heavy rainfall to occur in a short period of time, especially from the Florida Panhandle through Southeastern Alabama and into South Central Georgia. Rainfall amounts of 3 to 5 inches with isolated heavier amounts are possible with this storm system.
These amounts could lead to flash flooding during the time of heavy rainfall, especially if occurring in urbanized areas as well as leading to riverine and creek flooding in some of our more vulnerable basins in the days ahead, like the Pea River, the Choctawhatchee River, The Kinchafoonee and Muckalee Creeks, the Ochlockonee River and the Withlacoochee River.
The Weather Prediction Center has placed much of Southeast Alabama and a portion of Southwest Georgia in a moderate risk for excessive rainfall on Wednesday night, or a level 3 of 4 risk. This not only indicates increased confidence of heavy rainfall but also an increase in severity of flash flood impacts within the moderate risk area.
.Preparedness Information... There still remains some uncertainty as to where the heaviest rainfall will occur. However a flood watch will likely be issued for a portion of the area on Tuesday. Now is a good time to prepare if you live in an area vulnerable to flash flooding or riverine flooding. Flooding is especially dangerous at night. If you live in a flood zone, know your risk and be prepared to take action should heavier rainfall occur.
For the latest forecasts visit our website at https://weather. gov/tallahassee
